Award.AwardTitle: Centrifuge Modeling of Coastal Soil-Structure Instability

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2011 Japan Earthquake and Tsunami caused unprecedented damage and loss of lives in Japan. This large earthquake created long-duration ground shaking followed by giant tsunami inundation. Post-event reconnaissance teams have reported that damage to buildings and infrastructure was often exacerbated or caused by soil instability. Understanding how combined earthquake and tsunami events affect soil instability is crucial to prepare for similar impending earthquake-tsunami events that have affected coastal areas of the United States in the past. During an earthquake, soil instability is primarily caused by liquefaction; that is, the soil acts like a liquid, and the potential for the soil to support overlying buildings and infrastructure is severely reduced. Liquefaction can also occur during the tsunami inundation in addition to scouring at the surface caused by the water current. This research will advance the understanding of soil instability caused by the combined effects of earthquakes and tsunamis. Effective strategies for designing resilient critical buildings and infrastructure will be developed. As part of this program, a graduate student will be educated in the fundamentals of geo-and-fluid mechanics, which will prepare her to become an interdisciplinary multi-natural hazards researcher. A series of education videos will be created for the purpose of encouraging college and high school students to pursue careers in science and engineering.

With regards to the 2011 Event, it is suspected that soil instability was first triggered by the earthquake, presumably via residual liquefaction and fluidization, and then further promoted by the ensuing tsunami, presumably via momentary liquefaction and scour. This hypothesis produces the questions: (1) How does earthquake-induced soil instability interact with tsunami-induced soil instability? (2) How does the elapsed time between the earthquake and tsunami affect this interaction? (3) Is enhanced scour around coastal structures worsened by the combined earthquake-tsunami multi-hazard? To answer these questions, laboratory experiments will be performed using the UC Davis Centrifuge Facility. The centrifuge is the only experimental apparatus capable of imposing successive earthquake-tsunami loading on prototypical soil-fluid-structure systems. The centrifuge experiments will aim to reveal fundamental mechanisms of soil instability caused by successive earthquake-tsunami loads and in turn, discover how this loading scenario affects soil-fluid-structure systems. The high quality and unique data obtained from the precisely controlled experiments will be invaluable for benchmarking and validating analytical and numerical prediction models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2011 Japan Tsunami caused significant and unanticipated damage to buildings and infrastructure. For a typical tsunami, the water surface near the shore fluctuates with amplitude of several meters for a period of a few to tens of minutes, which is different from storm waves and river-flood flows. The mechanisms of soil instability due to tsunamis need to be understood in order to appropriately design and protect critical buildings and coastal infrastructure. 

The research topic is complex because of its large scale and transient nature involved in the multi-phase (air-water-soil) media. Because a theoretical model for soil response to such large transient loading on the surface has not been established, we must first focus on the soil-response mechanism, and must resort to careful experiments in a controlled laboratory environment. This research chose to use the NHERI’s geotechnical centrifuge equipment at the University of California, Davis.

While centrifuges have been used regularly for studies of geotechnical engineering problems, it has been rarely used for research on water flows. We developed a unique apparatus specifically designed and constructed for the centrifuge to study tsunami-like loadings on soils. It is capable of exploring soil/flow mechanics by realistically simulating tsunami runup and drawdown processes.

For our research, we performed the experiments by setting the 40-g centripetal acceleration. This conveniently means that the geometric scale of the model is 1/40 of the prototype. The model is equivalent to the following prototype scales. 

  • The sediment model in the specimen box (53.3 cm long, 36.4 cm wide, 25 cm deep) represents the prototype soil field of 21 m long, 14.6 m wide and 9.5 m deep.
  • The water inundation depth (11.5 cm) in the model represents 4.6 m deep in the corresponding prototype.
  • The surging speed is between 7 and 9 m/s in both model and prototype. 

It is important to point out that the pressures and flow velocities in the model are identical to those of the prototype, which yield realistic conditions of flow-soil interactions, minimizing the scale effect. To our knowledge, there does not exist any laboratory facility capable of creating the foregoing laboratory conditions under the normal gravitational condition. The centrifuge can make such experiments possible.

With the use of our developed apparatus, we performed several experiments. For the 2017 campaign, we found two new mechanisms. First, the soil specimen exhibits a faster pressure transmission within the soil than the propagation of the water-flow surge. This is an important finding, and can be explained by the difference in the pressure transmission speed between the free-surface flows and the confined flows in the soil medium. Water-wave pressure propagates with the deformation of the water surface, while the pressure within the fully saturated soil can transmit faster than the free-surface surge motion due to its semi-confined medium. The foregoing finding is reported in the publication by Exton et al. (2019).

Another outcome from the 2017 program is the mechanism for tsunami-induced boulder transports. There is much reported evidence of boulder transport and deposition caused by tsunamis. Tsunami-transported boulders can provide valuable information about historical tsunami events, and therefore contribute to the record of the frequency and magnitude of significant tsunami events. In our research, we focused on the mechanism for the incipient detachment of the boulder embedded in the soil due to the leading tsunami surge front. Based on the experiments, we found that the inertial force is not responsible for initiating boulder pickup, and, when a spherical-shaped boulder is at least one-half buried in the soil, the only mechanism that causes the rotational motion is the net lift force. Our experimental results demonstrate that the transport process cannot be predicted by the previous approach: force and moment balance by a linear combination of drag, lift, inertial, and body forces. Our evaluation suggests that the presence of a shallow-water surface that is comparable to the boulder dimension has an impact on the fluid forces applied to the boulders. This finding is reported in a publication by Harry et al. (2019).

We performed two sets of experiments in 2018 to examine the effects of an impermeable horizontal layer embedded near the soil surface: this can be considered to be a situation of less permeable clay layer within sandy soil or the presence of pavement or building’s mat foundation. The laboratory results are currently being analyzed, but the effect of the presence of the layer was found to be substantial. The pore-water-pressure response under the layer is different from the case without the layer. The findings are presented in a PhD thesis by Exton (2019).
